title: The Evolutionary Origins of Friendship: A Cross-Species Comparison and Experimental Approach
descriptions:
The grant proposal titled "The Evolutionary Origins of Friendship: A Cross-Species Comparison and Experimental Approach" aims to investigate the importance of friendship in human health and well-being, public health, and political policy. The project seeks to address the risks associated with social isolation and heart disease by comparing social behaviors in heavy smokers, drinkers, and obese individuals. 

The focus of the study is on the evolutionary origins of friendship and human specializations in social relationships. By utilizing a cross-species dataset and conducting social experiments with nonhuman primates and macaques, the project will test environmental forces driving variation in social bonds across species. Additionally, the research aims to determine if having information on the friendships of unrelated others is a uniquely human skill and whether social isolation is a result of competitive exclusion.

The outcomes of this project will contribute to a better understanding of the evolutionary perspective of friendship, shedding light on the fundamental aspects of human social behavior. By gaining insight into the origins of friendship, this research will provide valuable information for improving human health outcomes and informing public policy decisions. Understanding friendship from an evolutionary perspective is essential for comprehending the complexities of human social interactions and what it means to be human.
